discussion_comments.comment_body:
Just thinking this through:

Model parameters might still be used because Aider has defaults for each mode. However, chat modes often do not behave identically to API mode of the same model, for various reasons. It might be best to use aider defaults for that model now, which would require setting the model still.

`--copy-paste` model settings may be required, otherwise aider will fallback to the user default, which may have the wrong settings.

As I was thinking through the original --copy-paste I realized that it splits the `/code` model features in a way not typically possible with API. My current understanding is that in `/code` mode, the editor model plans and codes the feature, whereas in --copy-paste, the chat model plans, and the --editor-model codes.

> However, chat modes often do not behave identically to API mode of the same model, for various reasons.

I agree, is there some documentation about what parameters chat models use compared to their API counterpart? would be interesting.

> It might be best to use aider defaults for that model now, which would require setting the model still.

without documentation about chat model parameters, it seems best to explicitly set the model and assume the same parameters as for the API.

> As I was thinking through the original --copy-paste I realized that it splits the /code model features in a way not typically possible with API. My current understanding is that in /code mode, the editor model plans and codes the feature, whereas in --copy-paste, the chat model plans, and the --editor-model codes.

yeah, the original copy-paste mode has a different architectural approach. as far as I understand, the chat model comes up with a plan, the user copy/pastes the plan, and the plan is injected into aider's chat. this chat containing the plan is sent to the editor model via the litellm API backend. and the editor model diffs are applied to the code.
